Definition: In this task, you will be given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. Head and Tail are events that are short and may involve participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words. PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head includes an event or action from the Tail. This happens when the Tail is a smaller part of the Head event. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", which is a placeholder for an object, person, and/or action.
Domains: Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Physical Commonsense
Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Social Commonsense

Positive Examples.input: Head: have conversation<sep>Tail: choose subject to discuss
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. The Head includes the event of choosing a subject the Tail.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX allergic to bees<sep>Tail: none
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, there isn't any action or event in the Tail. So the output should be"No".
In this example, designing software includes checking the design. Thus, this example should be classified as "Yes".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX asks to go home<sep>Tail: to go rest
Negative Examples.explanation: Asking to go home doesn't include going rest. So the output should be "No".
The communicate includes gathering the thoughts, and the output should be "Yes".

Instances.input: Head: PersonX applies for a loan<sep>Tail: curious
Head: PersonX asks for the moon<sep>Tail: impractical
Head: tape television show<sep>Tail: program vcr
Head: sue<sep>Tail: prepare to spend lots of money
Head: test car<sep>Tail: turn car off
Head: PersonX asks if PersonY was okay<sep>Tail: caring
